subSections.title: Compounds
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}} {{wikipedia|Celtis sinensis}} [[File:Celtis_sinensis%3DChinese_Hackberry.jpg|thumb|250px|{{m|ja|榎|tr=e, enoki}}: the '''[[Chinese hackberry]] [[tree]]'''.]]
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|え}} From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=え|-}}. Found in the ''{{w|Man'yōshū}}'', completed some time after 759 CE.{{RQ:Manyoshu|16|3872}}, text [http://jti.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/manyoshu/Man16Yo.html#3872 here] There are various theories regarding the ultimate derivation of this ''e''. Some of these include: * From {{m|ja|枝||tr=e, eda|branch}}, from the many [[branch]]es * From {{m|ja|餌||tr=e, esa|food for animals}}, from the multitude of berries eaten by birds * From {{m|ja|柄||tr=e|handle}}, from the way the wood was used for [[tool]] [[handle]]s

subSections.title: Noun
Usage notes
subSections.text: This reading is generally not used in isolation in modern Japanese.

subSections.title: Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|えのき}}

Compound of {{compound|ja|sort=えのき|榎|tr1=e|t1=[[Chinese hackberry]]|の|tr2=no|pos2=possessive particle|木|tr3=ki|t3=[[tree]]}}.  Compare the similar formation of various other tree names, such as {{m|ja|楠||tr=kusu|camphor; camphor tree}} and {{m|ja|楠||tr=kusunoki|camphor tree}}.

subSections.title: Noun
subSections.text:
{{ja-noun|えのき|エノキ}}

# {{taxlink|Celtis sinensis|species}}, the [[Chinese hackberry]] [[tree]]
